description.narrative: Reduced risk of the burden of diarrhoeal diseases from exposure to inadequate water, sanitation and hand hygiene practices among children (girls and boys) in Somalia.

UNICEF had applied to Sida for funding of SEK 75 million to carry out an intervention titled “Improving Children’s Access to Water and Sanitation in Somalia” during the period 2015-2018. The application was later revised to SEK 40 million to fit within the available fund allocation.
The intervention aims at ensuring more communities use sustained Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) services and are empowered to stop harmful sanitation and hygiene behaviors by: 1) Increasing access of women, boys and girls to improved water sources in institutions and catchment areas, 2) increasing access to improved and gender responsive sanitation facilities in schools, 3) improving protective sanitation and hygiene practices to eliminate open defecation, and 4) increasing capacity of stakeholders and systems to plan for, monitor and manage gender responsive WASH services. UNICEF will implement the intervention in collaboration with the line government ministries, local government authorities, Non-Governmental Organizations and the civil society.
The intervention’s total budget is SEK 40 million for four years of which Sweden will fund SEK 40 Million for four years.

UNICEF har inkommit med en förfrågan om stöd om 75 MSEK för att implementera ett projekt för ”Förbättrad tillgång på vatten och sanitet i Somalia” under perioden 2015-2018. Budgeten har begränsats till 40 MSEK för att passa med den svenska medelstilldelningen.
Insatsen syftar till att säkerställa att fler människor använder hållbara vatten, sanitet och hygien (WASH) tjänster och att människor har möjlighet att undvika ohälsosamma beteenden gällande sanitet och hygien. Detta kommer uppnås genom: 1) Ökad tillgång till förbättrade vattenkällor på institutioner och avrinningsområden för kvinnor, pojkar och flickor, 2) ökad tillgång till förbättrade sanitetsanläggningar i skolorna, med ett särskilt focks på flickor, 3) förbättrat sanitet- och hygienbeteende för att eliminera öppen defekation, och 4) att öka kapaciteten hos offentliga institutioner för att planera för, övervaka och hantera WASH tjänster. UNICEF kommer att genomföra insatser i samarbete med linjeministerier, lokala myndigheter, icke-statliga organisationer och det civila samhället.
Projektets totala budget är 40 miljoner kronor under fyra år utav vilket Sverige kommer att finansiera 40 miljoner kronor under fyra år.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: 1) A total of 140,653 people of the targeted 150,000 , mainly women and children, were reached with improved access to safe and sustainable water supply. 2) The project provided access to safe excreta disposal for a total of 36,890 people including school children, through rehabilitation and construction of sanitation facilities in schools and health facilities. 3) To reduce open defecation and attain Open Defecation Free (ODF) status through Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS), 38 communities were reached out of which 23 were certified as ODF 4) The WASH in Schools component reached 14,926 children (7,537 girls; 7,389 boys) were reached through latrine construction, rehabilitation or menstrual hygiene management activities. 5) Draft WASH policy and developed and stakeholder consultations held.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
